translations.rules.title: Blackjack Rules - How the Card Game Works
translations.rules.intro: Blackjack (also called "21") is one of the most popular card games worldwide. On this page, we explain the official game rules simply and clearly.
translations.rules.goal.title: The Goal of Blackjack
translations.rules.goal.p1: The goal in Blackjack is simple: Get a card total as close to 21 as possible - but don't exceed it. At the same time, you must beat the dealer by either having more points or by the dealer "busting" (going over 21).
translations.rules.goal.p2: A "Blackjack" (also called Natural) is the best possible hand: An Ace combined with a 10, Jack, Queen, or King. This combination beats all other hands.
translations.rules.cardValues.title: Card Values Overview
translations.rules.cardValues.intro: Card values in Blackjack are easy to remember:
translations.rules.cardValues.faces: Face cards (Jack, Queen, King): Count 10 points each
translations.rules.cardValues.ace: Ace: Counts 1 or 11 points - whichever is more favorable for your hand
translations.rules.cardValues.link: ‚Üí More about card values and Soft/Hard Hands
translations.rules.gameplay.title: Gameplay Step by Step
translations.rules.gameplay.step1: Place your bet: Before each round, you place your wager (chip).
translations.rules.gameplay.step2: Cards are dealt: You receive two face-up cards, the dealer gets one face-up and one face-down card.
translations.rules.gameplay.step3: Player decision: You decide whether to draw more cards (Hit), stay (Stand), double down (Double), or split pairs (Split).
translations.rules.gameplay.step4: Dealer draws: After all players finish, the dealer reveals their card and draws according to fixed rules.
translations.rules.gameplay.step5: Evaluation: Whoever is closer to 21 wins - without busting.
translations.rules.dealer.title: Dealer Rules
translations.rules.dealer.intro: The dealer plays by fixed rules - they have no choice. The most common variant:
translations.rules.dealer.rule1: Dealer must hit on 16 or less
translations.rules.dealer.rule2: Dealer must stand on 17 or more
translations.rules.dealer.rule3: On "Soft 17" (Ace + 6), the rule varies by casino
translations.rules.dealer.outro: These fixed rules are why you can gain a mathematical edge with the right strategy.
translations.rules.winning.title: When Do You Win?
translations.rules.cta.title: Apply the Rules Now
translations.rules.cta.text: Now you know the basic rules. As a next step, we recommend learning the optimal Blackjack strategy or practicing directly in training mode.

translations.strategy.title: Blackjack Strategy - The Optimal Basic Strategy
translations.strategy.intro: The "Basic Strategy" is the mathematically optimal way to play Blackjack. With it, you reduce the house edge to under 0.5% and make the best possible decision in every situation.
translations.strategy.whatIs.title: What is Basic Strategy?
translations.strategy.whatIs.p1: Basic Strategy was developed in the 1960s through computer analysis. It's based on probability theory and considers:
translations.strategy.whatIs.factor3: Whether you have a Soft Hand, Hard Hand, or Pair
translations.strategy.whatIs.p2: For every possible combination, there's exactly one optimal action. The good news: You don't need to calculate - just memorize the chart.
translations.strategy.hardHands.title: Hard Hands Strategy
translations.strategy.hardHands.intro: For Hard Hands (no Ace counting as 11), the rules of thumb are:
translations.strategy.softHands.title: Soft Hands Strategy
translations.strategy.softHands.intro: For Soft Hands (Ace counts as 11), you can play more aggressively since there's no immediate bust risk:
translations.strategy.pairs.title: Pairs (Splitting) Strategy
translations.strategy.pairs.intro: For Pairs, you decide whether to Split. Key rules:
translations.strategy.houseEdge.title: House Edge and Winning Odds
translations.strategy.houseEdge.p1: With perfect Basic Strategy, you reduce the house edge to about 0.4-0.5%. This means: For every ‚Ç¨100 wagered, you lose on average only 40-50 cents.
translations.strategy.houseEdge.p2: Important: Basic Strategy doesn't guarantee wins, but it gives you the best mathematical odds for long-term success.
translations.strategy.tips.title: Practical Learning Tips
translations.strategy.tips.tip1: Learn in blocks: First Hard Hands, then Soft Hands, then Pairs
translations.strategy.tips.tip2: Use mnemonics: "Eights and Aces - always split the cases"
translations.strategy.tips.tip3: Practice regularly: Our training mode gives you instant feedback
translations.strategy.tips.tip4: No deviations: The strategy only works if you apply it consistently
translations.strategy.cta.title: Train the Strategy Now
translations.strategy.cta.text: Theory is good, practice is better. In interactive training, you learn Basic Strategy step by step - with instant feedback on every decision.

translations.glossary.title: Blackjack Glossary - All Terms Explained
translations.glossary.intro: From "Hit" to "Surrender": Here you'll find all important Blackjack terms explained simply and clearly. Perfect for looking up while playing or learning.
translations.glossary.terms.title: Important Blackjack Terms
translations.glossary.quickRef.title: Quick Reference: The 4 Main Actions
translations.glossary.cta.title: Learn Terms in Practice
translations.glossary.cta.text: In training mode, you apply the terms directly. Or first read the game rules and Basic Strategy.
translations.glossary.def.blackjack: The game itself and the best possible hand: An Ace + a 10-value card as starting hand. Pays 3:2.
translations.glossary.def.hit: Request another card from the dealer. You can Hit as many times as you want, as long as you stay under 21.
translations.glossary.def.stand: Keep your current card total and draw no more cards. The dealer plays next.
translations.glossary.def.double: Double your bet and receive exactly one more card. You must then stand automatically. Especially profitable with 10 or 11 points.
translations.glossary.def.split: Divide a pair (two cards of equal value) into two separate hands. You must place an additional bet equal to your original for the second hand.
translations.glossary.def.bust: Going over 21 points. Whoever busts loses immediately - regardless of the dealer's hand.
translations.glossary.def.push: A tie between player and dealer (same point total). Your bet is returned, no win or loss.
translations.glossary.def.insurance: Optional side bet when the dealer shows an Ace. Pays 2:1 if the dealer has Blackjack. Mathematically unfavorable and not recommended.
translations.glossary.def.softHand: A hand with an Ace counted as 11 (e.g., A+6 = Soft 17). You can draw more cards with less risk on a Soft Hand.
translations.glossary.def.hardHand: A hand without an Ace, or with an Ace that must count as 1 to stay under 21. Hard Hands have real bust risk.
translations.glossary.def.upcard: The dealer's face-up card that all players can see. It's the basis for all strategic decisions.
translations.glossary.def.holeCard: The dealer's face-down card, revealed only after all players have made their decisions.
translations.glossary.def.natural: Another term for a Blackjack (Ace + 10-value card as starting hand).
translations.glossary.def.shoe: The card holder from which cards are drawn. Usually contains 6 or 8 decks.
translations.glossary.def.bankroll: Your total budget available for playing. Good bankroll management is crucial for long-term enjoyment.
translations.glossary.def.basicStrategy: The mathematically optimal way to play for every possible card combination. Reduces the house edge to under 0.5%.
translations.glossary.def.houseEdge: The casino's mathematical advantage. In Blackjack with Basic Strategy, it's about 0.5% - one of the lowest of all casino games.
translations.glossary.def.surrender: Allowed in some casinos: Give up your hand and get half your bet back. Rarely offered.
translations.glossary.seo.headline: Blackjack Glossary - All Terms Explained
translations.glossary.seo.articleDesc: From Hit to Surrender: All important Blackjack terms explained simply and clearly.
translations.glossary.seo.title: Blackjack Glossary - Terms from A to Z
translations.glossary.seo.description: Blackjack terms explained: Hit, Stand, Double, Split, Bust, Insurance, and more. The complete glossary for beginners and advanced players.
translations.glossary.seo.keywords: Blackjack Terms, Blackjack Glossary, Blackjack Dictionary, Hit Stand Double Split, Blackjack Terminology
translations.faq.title: Blackjack FAQ - Frequently Asked Questions
translations.faq.intro: Here you'll find answers to the most frequently asked questions about Blackjack, Basic Strategy, and our trainer.
translations.faq.questions.title: Frequently Asked Questions
translations.faq.resources.title: Additional Resources
translations.faq.resources.intro: Your question wasn't answered? Find more information in our other articles:
translations.faq.resources.gameplay: How to Play Blackjack - Step by Step
translations.faq.resources.glossary: Glossary - All Terms from A to Z
translations.faq.cta.title: Have More Questions?
translations.faq.cta.text: The best way to learn is through practice. Start the free training now and learn Basic Strategy step by step.
translations.faq.q1.question: What is the difference between "Blackjack" and "Black Jack"?
translations.faq.q1.answer: Both spellings are correct and refer to the same card game. "Blackjack" (one word) is more common internationally. "Black Jack" (two words) is sometimes used. In our trainer, we use both variants as players search for both terms.
translations.faq.q2.question: What is Basic Strategy and why should I learn it?
translations.faq.q2.answer: Basic Strategy is the mathematically optimal way to play Blackjack. It was developed through computer analysis and tells you for every card combination whether to Hit, Stand, Double, or Split. With Basic Strategy, you reduce the casino's house edge to under 0.5% - one of the lowest of all casino games.
translations.faq.q3.question: How does the Ace count in Blackjack?
translations.faq.q3.answer: The Ace is the most flexible card in Blackjack: It can count as 1 or 11 points - whichever is better for your hand. For example, if you have an Ace and a 6, that counts as Soft 17 (Ace = 11). If you then draw an 8, the Ace automatically downgrades to 1, so you stay at 15 points instead of 25 (Bust).
translations.faq.q4.question: When should I split?
translations.faq.q4.answer: The two most important rules: Always split Aces and Eights, never split Tens and Fives. Splitting Aces gives you two chances at a Blackjack. Splitting Eights turns a weak 16 into two playable hands. Tens (value: 20) are already very strong, and Fives (value: 10) are better doubled.
translations.faq.q5.question: What does "Double Down" mean?
translations.faq.q5.answer: With Double Down, you double your bet and receive exactly one more card. Then you must stand. This option is especially profitable with 10 or 11 points when the dealer shows a weak card - you have good chances of a high final total.
translations.faq.q6.question: Is the Blackjack Trainer free?
translations.faq.q6.answer: Yes, our Blackjack Trainer is completely free. You can practice Basic Strategy unlimited and play Blackjack in game mode - without registration and without real money. It's a pure practice tool without gambling.
translations.faq.q7.question: What's the difference between Soft Hand and Hard Hand?
translations.faq.q7.answer: A Soft Hand contains an Ace counted as 11 (e.g., A+7 = Soft 18). You can draw more cards with less risk because the Ace can downgrade to 1 if needed. A Hard Hand has either no Ace or the Ace must count as 1. Hard Hands have real bust risk.
translations.faq.q8.question: Should I take Insurance?
translations.faq.q8.answer: No. Insurance is offered when the dealer shows an Ace. It pays 2:1 if the dealer has Blackjack. Mathematically, you lose money long-term with this side bet - the house edge is over 7%. Basic Strategy recommends: Never take Insurance.
translations.faq.q9.question: Can I guarantee wins with Basic Strategy?
translations.faq.q9.answer: No, even with perfect Basic Strategy you won't win every hand. Blackjack remains a game of chance. However, Basic Strategy minimizes the house edge to about 0.5%. That means: Short-term anything is possible, but long-term you lose on average only 50 cents per ‚Ç¨100 wagered - one of the fairest values of all casino games.
translations.faq.q10.question: How can I best learn Basic Strategy?
translations.faq.q10.answer: The most effective way is in three steps: First Hard Hands, then Soft Hands, then Pairs (Splits). Use our training mode, which gives you instant feedback after every decision. 15-20 minutes of daily practice over 1-2 weeks is usually enough to internalize the strategy.

translations.faq.seo.description: Answers to the most common Blackjack questions: Basic Strategy, Ace rules, Double Down, Split, and more. Explained for beginners.

translations.gameplay.title: How to Play Blackjack - Beginner's Guide
translations.gameplay.intro: Want to learn Blackjack? This step-by-step guide shows you how a round works and what decisions you can make.
translations.gameplay.prep.title: Before You Start: Preparation
translations.gameplay.prep.text: Blackjack is played with one or more card decks. You sit opposite the dealer at the table. Before cards are dealt, you must place your bet in the betting field.
translations.gameplay.prep.tipText: Decide before playing how much you want to bet maximum. Good bankroll management is more important than any strategy.
translations.gameplay.step1.title: Step 1: Cards Are Dealt
translations.gameplay.step1.text: After betting, you receive two cards - both face up. The dealer also gets two cards, but only one is face up (the "Upcard"). The face-down card is called the "Hole Card".
translations.gameplay.step1.exampleText: You receive a 10 and a 7 (= 17 points). The dealer shows a 6.
translations.gameplay.step2.title: Step 2: Your Options
translations.gameplay.step2.intro: Now it's your turn. You have the following actions available:
translations.gameplay.step2.hit.title: Hit (Draw a Card)
translations.gameplay.step2.hit.text: You request another card. You can Hit as many times as you want as long as you stay under 21. If you exceed 21, you "bust" and lose immediately.
translations.gameplay.step2.stand.title: Stand (Keep Current Hand)
translations.gameplay.step2.stand.text: You're satisfied with your current point total and draw no more cards. The dealer plays next.
translations.gameplay.step2.double.title: Double Down
translations.gameplay.step2.double.text: You double your bet and receive exactly one more card. Then you must stand automatically. This option is especially useful with 9, 10, or 11 points.
translations.gameplay.step2.split.title: Split
translations.gameplay.step2.split.text: If you have a pair (e.g., two 8s), you can split the hand and continue playing with two separate hands. You must place an additional bet for the second hand.
translations.gameplay.step3.title: Step 3: The Dealer Plays
translations.gameplay.step3.text: Once all players are done, the dealer reveals their Hole Card. The dealer has no choice - they must play by fixed rules:
translations.gameplay.step3.rule1: At 16 or less: Dealer must hit
translations.gameplay.step3.rule2: At 17 or more: Dealer must stand
translations.gameplay.step3.outro: If the dealer busts, all players still in the game win.
translations.gameplay.step4.title: Step 4: Evaluation and Payout
translations.gameplay.step4.intro: After the dealer's turn, hands are compared:
translations.gameplay.step4.lose: Dealer has more: You lose your bet
translations.gameplay.example.title: A Complete Example Round
translations.gameplay.cta.title: Ready to Practice?
translations.gameplay.cta.text: Now you know the gameplay. Test your knowledge in the free training mode or play a round in the simulator.

translations.cardValues.title: Blackjack Card Values - Soft Hands, Hard Hands & Ace Rules
translations.cardValues.intro: In Blackjack, every card has a fixed point value. Especially important: The Ace can be counted flexibly. Here you'll learn everything about card values and the difference between Soft and Hard Hands.
translations.cardValues.overview.title: Card Values Overview
translations.cardValues.overview.note: Card suits (Hearts, Diamonds, Spades, Clubs) don't matter in Blackjack - only the numerical value counts.
translations.cardValues.ace.title: The Ace - The Most Flexible Card
translations.cardValues.ace.text: The Ace is the most powerful card in Blackjack. It can count as either 1 or 11 points - whichever is more favorable for your hand.
translations.cardValues.ace.example3: Ace + 5 + 8 = 14 (Ace counts as 1, otherwise it would be 24 = Bust)
translations.cardValues.ace.note: The Ace automatically downgrades to 1 when you would otherwise bust.
translations.cardValues.softHand.title: What is a Soft Hand?
translations.cardValues.softHand.text: A Soft Hand is a hand with an Ace counted as 11. You can't draw a card that immediately busts you - the Ace simply downgrades to 1.
translations.cardValues.softHand.note: Soft Hands are strategically valuable because you can draw more cards with less risk.
translations.cardValues.hardHand.title: What is a Hard Hand?
translations.cardValues.hardHand.text: A Hard Hand has either no Ace or the Ace must count as 1 to stay under 21. Hard Hands have real bust risk when drawing.
translations.cardValues.hardHand.example1Note: No Ace, bust danger on Hit
translations.cardValues.pairs.title: Pairs and Splitting
translations.cardValues.pairs.intro: If you receive two cards of equal value (e.g., 8-8 or K-K), you can "split" and play two separate hands. Pair strategy is especially important:
translations.cardValues.blackjack.title: The Blackjack (Natural 21)
translations.cardValues.blackjack.intro: A "Blackjack" is the best hand in the game: An Ace + a 10-value card (10, J, Q, K) as starting hand. This combination:
translations.cardValues.blackjack.instant: Wins instantly, unless dealer also has Blackjack (Push)
translations.cardValues.blackjack.warningText: Some casinos only pay Blackjack at 6:5. This significantly worsens your odds - avoid such tables.
translations.cardValues.cta.title: Practice Card Values
translations.cardValues.cta.text: In training mode, you automatically learn to distinguish Soft and Hard Hands and make the right decision.
